comments.commentBody: So what are you proposing we do now that Maliki has shown that he can't field an army that can stand up to a stiff breeze. Are you suggesting that we re - up for another go at it? Rather than complain about Obama how about a little humility about the Bush administration's complete failure to plan for the aftermath of the war, and the utter incompetence and stupidity in the way they managed the occupation of Iraq. By the time Obama took office the chance to win the peace was long passed. We invaded Iraq without good reason and mishandled the occupation,  all of which were done by the Bush people and their neoconservative cheerleaders. Obama cleaned up their mess as best he could, no thanks to people like yourself.

The violence and killing was even worse in 2006-07. The agreement to withdraw by 12/31/11 was negotiated by the Bush administration. The current situation is the fault of the Maliki government's sectarian policies.

US foreign policy is largely failing because we are intruding in places where we have no business -- places like Iraq, Libya, and Ukraine. Imagine if the US had gone back to being "a normal country in a normal time" as Jeane Kirkpatrick wrote in a famous 1990 article. How different our lives today would be!

My Dear Mr Silen .... I made two points. First, a motley assortment of lefties, defeatists, pacifists, and Democrats incessantly assured us that violence in Iraq was caused by the presence of U.S. troops and violence would end with the withdrawal of those troops. Well, the troops are gone but sadly not the violence. Along these lines allow me to refer to a 2008 quote from candidate Obama, " let's not leave Iraq as stupidly as we got int Iraq ". My second point is that the Obama " resets " have seemed to go awry; e.g. Libya, Russia, Syria, the pivot ( has there really been such? ) to Asia. The implication of this point is that possibly Obama is not the brightest bulb in the chandelier when it comes to foreign policy.

For years assorted lefties, defeatists, and Democrats howled and insisted that the violence was caused by the American troop presence and that violence would subside and peace would be restored if and when U.S. troops left the country. Well, they have left the country. Obama pulled out all troops by 31 Dec 2011. What happened? The violence and killing are at record levels. ISIS and al Qaeda affiliates are curving out a swath of controlled territory from eastern Syria through the middle of Iraq to the Euphrates River, a sanctuary for the launching of terrorist attacks around the world as North American and European Islamic terrorists return to their adopted countries and put their training into action throughout the western world. Current foreign policy is becoming a litany of failure: Libya, Crimea/Ukraine, Iraq, Afghanistan, Syria, the China Seas.

Voters may not have know what they were voting for? Don't voters have any other sources of info on candidates besides the candidates own ads? That's the least reliable, most manipulative source.

They could easily peek in a few newspapers to see a list of the candidates' positions on various issues. Look up their records, read a few columnists from the right and left. Ads are the campaigns biggest expense, and what drives candidates to seek the big donor money, with bad consequences for us all.

In the age of the internet, why do voters even watch ads? I never do--can't stomach it.

Who knows? Why? With the small population of this Virginia district, it hardly speaks for the nation as a whole (that's one of the main points of statistics anyway, sample size).

Immigration is not enough. Its not about policy. But Eric's Slick Style was a loser in the end.

What's really interesting is not why it happened (who knows? too small a sample, etc) but how it is being spun, and for who's benefit? Just read WSJ's coverage. A comparative study from a range of media would be telling. The media is in the process of writing "why" it append, right in front of our eyes.

You probably know I collect professional Japanese knives, which are worthy of veneration. I feel like I'm using blades forged in the fires of Mordor. One of them splits a live 4-pound lobster in half like it's a melon. And it's sharp enough to shave with.

I take a basic set of seven knives to Seattle for my New Years cooking. No matter how I word the note to the TSA, someone always cuts himself inspecting our baggage. I don't mind the blood stains on the clothing but these knives are not stainless, and the blood leaves a mark on the blade that won't polish out. I don't even know why they have to feel the edge after they unsheathe a knife anyway. But they always do and always get nicked.
Martin, if anyone doesn't look like a terrorist I'm sure it's you.  TSA stands for The Stupid A___h___s.

I'm just throwing this in here to see how badly tangled a thread can become.

Thanks for the the watermelon story, John. I had a wonderful vision of you doing a Ninja warrior thingy with the melon. And of Martin shaving with a samurai sword.

Full-sized watermelons do pose a problem in sectioning: a guillotine would be appropriate. So now they've genetically devised the 'personal' watermelon, a quarter the size at twice the price. But John, *please* eschew the pre-minced garlic. The thought alone gives me physical pain.
Martin, what am I missing?  I thought this was supposed to be a Thursday puzzle.      Is it Wednesday?

Sorry, but this is incorrect. Northeast England is a distinct region, closer in many ways to Scotland, both geographically, politically and culturally, than the southern shires of England, which is where the mythical 'Little England' is located.

Actually the number of votes cast in this primary is significant.

The other two Virginia congressional primaries held on Tuesday only had 38855 and 17444 votes cast. That there were 65000 votes cast in the Virginia 7th district primary indicates the interest level.

And let's not leave out that this is the first time the majority leader in the House has failed to win his party's endorsement.

Living in England can become addictive.  I lived there for 3 years during the late 60's early 70's.  My cup runneth over with the music scene in London, but the rural countryside is where I lived and it captured me forever.  I lived in the Cotswolds, another place lost in time in England, or at least it was then.  But my favorite trip around the aisle was to the northeast, to where my Uncle flew bombers over Germany during WW2.  He always spoke fondly of that area and I proposed to visit.  I found the people friendly, interesting and interested.  Whatever gods steered me that way will always be worshipped within my heart and soul.

Yes. My reasoning was worse than naive... it was based mostly on emotion!  My message was sent while I was somewhat in a state of Euphoria.  There is a libertarian in the race in NOV leaving the possibility open for a split conservative ticket. I am pretty motivated to work for dems to get out the vote.  given that Brat is a crackpot, we may have a major opportunity here!

Then there is Cullercoats where the most important American painter of his generation, Winslow Homer, spent some months in 1881 recording both the nobility and the grim struggles of the fisherfolk there. He recorded the women with particular power since it was they who wrestled within dangerous existence along that coast and became the symbol fro him of that life. That experience focused and changed Homer's art. Once he relocated himself back home on the coast of Maine, themes of man and the sea came to dominate his art for much the rest of his life. Remarkably, Cullercoats seems very little changed since those days and many of Homer's motifs can still be easily located there.

Steve:

You expressed my thoughts exactly. This Democrat would have voted against Cantor if I lived in 7th Virginia. One wonders if a few thousand people did so just because they were able to do so. That might explain why the polls were so far off - nobody polled Democrats about that primary race.
Thank you, Ms. Smiley, for such beautiful writing. I fall in love all over again with England every time I go there, but this time you saved me the trip.
Book into the Waren House Hotel, Waren Mill for wonderful friendly attentive staff and superb breakfast and dinner.  Then eat lunch at the Mizen Head in Bamburgh.
Though of course a fair amount of it is shot in Tyne and Wear. It's great fun to guess the spot!
Gorgeous descriptive writing. I could feel I was there. Ahhhhh, if only.
Ms. Smiley, thank you for this.
I agree about Whitby fish 'n chips. I'm 87 and haven't been back to the UK in a few years but reading this makes me want to make another trip and this time north of Yorkshire ....where I'm from.
Agree, a formidable Red Devils line up!  But as with the US, it will hinge on defense.

@cpm:
Yes, fully aware. Are you aware that in 1978, at the end of the second half of a 1-1 match, Robbie Rensenbrink of Holland hit the post against Argentina?
In 1986, it took a late Jorge Burruchaga goal to break a tie against West Germany?
In 1994, Brazil thrashed Italy...in penalty kicks.
It's not like there haven't been European teams that haven't come close in the Americas, sometimes painfully close. Maybe this is the year.
@vex: sure wish the USMNT had a defender the caliber of Kompany.

Personally, my money is on Spain or Germany to win the world cup depending on the draw after the first rounds they can meet each other. Brazil and Argentina may have the stars who dazzle, but not the teams with cohesion or endurance (see California Chrome) to go all the way. One of them could end up in the final against Spain of Germany, but more likely it will be a dark horse - England, Uruguay, or a team from Africa.

As for the US getting to the next round ... the "defense" carries the case. Good luck.

The wonderful thing is that MONEY lost big when Cantor fell. What if the Kochs and Adelson are wrong and Americans will revolt against the fat cats no matter how much money the superrich spend on brainwashing them on TV? If the public actually wakes up, the superrich won't be able to elect a dog-catcher outside of Greenwich and Boca--no matter how much money they throw at the problem of electing puppets.
Statiscally  it is a good sample and do not forget it.

"Economic theory has always held that wages should always be worked out per employer per situation."

As holder of an economics degree from Rutgers University, I would definitely classify this as a statement I'd expect from person with a 3-year old's knowledge of economics.

"shakes up house leadership."

Really? What leadership? we talking the usual "I don't care what it is but if it's anywhere close a whiff of, you know, Obama, the answer is no."

I guess that's leadership.

Akin to the blushing young lady who isn't quite sure what is wanted in a suitor so just finds it politic to say, ah, no.

A bad analogy, I grant, but our politics, Dems/GOP, would be really laughable if the distilled, conjoined stupidity wasn't so very deadly.

What happened to government?

Where was I when I got Old (87)?

Well, so much for GOP unity.  I'm sure the Wall St Journal will have a perfectly good reason why this is all healthful for the party and the defeat of Cantor is great for everyone.  But it destroys immigration reform and will cost the GOP the election in 2016.  But what the heck, they didn't want the White House anyway.

Maybe they also didn`t agree with his Israel first position either.

eg. While the Obama administration has been scrambling to find a way to try to salvage Israeli-Palestinian peace talks which have come to an impasse over resumed Israeli settlement building, Netanyahu has been sounding a triumphant note since he arrived in New Orleans over the weekend following the GOP gains in last Tuesday's midterm (2010) elections.

Last night, Netanyahu met in New York for over an hour with incoming House Majority Leader Rep. Eric Cantor (R-Va.), who is set to become the highest ranking Jewish member of Congress in history. The meeting took place at New York’s Regency Hotel, and included no other American lawmakers besides Cantor. Also attending on the Israeli side were Israeli Ambassador to the U.S. Michael Oren, and Netanyahu’s National Security Advisor Uzi Arad.

Israeli sources characterized a one-on-one meeting between an Israeli prime minister and a lone American lawmaker as unusual, if not unheard of.

Virginians are tired of Cantor and his diatribes.
Very happy to know he will be history.

I look forward to Cantor's inevitable book reciting his success in office. It should be a lengthy work - comparable to other literary epics such as: "A Vacation Guide To Detroit", "Great English Recipes", and "Famous Italian War Heroes".

I am aiming this comment at any pundit who will read it. Moderates are angry and we have no voice. I voted against Cantor on Tuesday because I am a moderate who hated what I perceived to be Cantor's unwillingness to deal and govern but my vote is being misconstrued as a vote FOR the Tea Party. I feel moderates have LOST our voice in America because of
-Gerrymandering resulting in pandering to the extreme wings of the party
-Unlimited contributions
-Cynicism among legislators who are more interested in lining their own pockets than going about the business of governing.
I want to elect a congress with COMMON SENSE. A congress that puts pragmatism above ideology and the people's needs above their own. A congress and a president that recognize that in the post-cold war era, the real threat to our country's future is a lack of shared purpose. What people want more than anything is to have a sense of purpose, of meaning,... the idea that what we do and who we are matters to those around us. I fault the Tea Party for not channeling their collective anger into something constructive. I fault the American political process for allowing Gerrymandering. I fault the media for not doing more to give free coverage to candidates who run for office at any level so that the public can be more informed when it comes time to vote.
